Award.AwardTitle: 36th Southeastern-Atlantic Regional Conference on Differential Equations 2016 (SEARCDE)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports participation in the thirty-sixth annual meeting of the Southeastern Atlantic Regional Conference on Differential Equations (SEARCDE), on November 5-6, 2016, at the Florida Gulf Coast University. The conference began in 1981 and has met annually since then, with the venue rotating among research institutions in the Southeast. The conference will serve as a forum for discussion and exchange of research ideas and recent developments in both theoretical and applied differential equations. In addition to four invited plenary lectures by leading international scholars in differential equations, there are twenty minute contributed talks given in parallel sessions. All participants will have the opportunity to present their work in these contributed talks, which are organized so that talks by established and senior researchers are interspersed with talks by beginning researchers. The conference tradition fosters an atmosphere conducive to networking and the creation of new research collaborations. SEARCDE especially encourages the participation of beginning researchers who get the opportunity to meet and hear renowned plenary speakers and senior researchers from the region. These opportunities are important for junior researchers, especially those from underrepresented groups. NSF funding ensures that many talented young researchers in applied mathematics will have the opportunity to participate in SEARCDE 2016.

The principal objective of the SEARCDE conference is to promote research and education in the field of differential equations by bringing together established and beginning researchers to exchange ideas and discuss recent developments. Among others the conference topics will include mathematical biology and epidemiology, dynamical systems approaches to partial differential equations, optimization, and optimal control and numerical analysis and simulation of solutions to PDEs. Proceedings of this conference will be published in Communications in Applied Analysis. Information about the conference can be found at the website, http://math.fgcu.edu/SEARCDE2016

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 36th Southeastern-Atlantic Regional Conference on Differential Equations (SEARCDE) was held in Florida for the first time in its history. The conference was held at Florida Gulf Coast University in Fort Myers, FL on November 5-6, 2017. The primary objective of SEARCDE is to promote research and education in the field of differential equations (and applied mathematics) by bringing together established and beginning researchers, including advanced undergraduate and graduate students, as well as recent Ph.D.s.

The two-day conference format includes four featured plenary lectures by internationally recognized leading researchers in both theoretical and applied differential equations, as well as parallel sessions of shorter lectures by both established and young researchers. All the titles and abstracts were reviewed by a local committee to determine their relevance to the conference focus. The 36th SEARCDE had 18 parallel sessions and four plenary talks. The conference format fosters opportunities for early career and student researchers to make new connections, to receive feedback on their work from more senior colleagues, and to begin possible research collaborations with scholars who complemented their research. There were a number of other opportunities for networking and mentoring throughout the conference, such as the breaks between parallel sessions.

The featured plenary lectures provided all attendees the opportunity to become aware of the latest research ideas and open problems in differential equations. The plenary speakers were Linda Allen (Texas Tech University), Peter Bates (Michigan State University), Avner Friedman (Ohio State University), and William Hager (University of Florida). All four plenary lectures were excellent and informative, and all four speakers gave generously of their time in speaking with other conference participants, especially junior researchers. For the first time in the history of the conference, proceeding will be published in Communications in Applied Analysis.

There were a total of 122 registered attendees, and 68 of them gave talks in the parallel sessions. The NSF funds provided support to 52 young researchers, which included 26 graduate students and 26 recent Ph.D. recipients. 

 


Last Modified: 01/19/2018
Modified by: Jaffar Ali Shahul-Hameed
